rev.comment: /* Law in the United States */ rm unsourced opinion statement
/* Law in Germany */ Removed this text because it does not address the law in Germany, but rather the actions of one company in that country.
Fixed single quotes, fancy quotes and apostrophes, and spaced em dash. Corrected hyphens to dashes. Fixed spacing. Logical punctuation. Fixed capitalization. Italicized foreign text and book titles..

/* Law in the European Union */ fix wrong reference URL
/* Law in Germany */ T-Mobile is a mobile telecommunication brand and does directly offer the landline access.
"opponents" here refers to a single person. Reference link does not support statement (and is dead anyway). The quip "solution in search of..." is pejorative B.S.
/* Law in the Russian Federation */ fixed dead link to Retracker
Removed link to "Blackout Europe", as it appears to be a site that sells window curtains and is therefore unrelated
Deleting self-promotion / third-party promotion for lack of valid citation. Cited source neither supports contention that Free Press filed complaint nor that Ammori drafted it.

/* Law in the Russian Federation */ +ref with DOI (computer.org) for retrackers and their usage and quote from article.
/* Law in the European Union */ In the first sentence, "legislation" was mistyped. Now its fixed.
/* Law in The Netherlands */ Clarifies that the Dutch bill still has a way to go before becoming law (and fixes spelling error).
The netherlands is part (founding member) of the european union so it should be clasified as a eu member
/* Law in The Netherlands */ add to ref

/* Law in the United States */ Ref name
/* FCC broadband policy statement */ Link went to wrong place, aded reference name
/* Law in the United States */ Dec. 21 update
/* FCC broadband policy statement */ Dec. 21 update
/* Proponents */ removed spurious liberal/conservative dichotomy, added by same user who moved "Opponents" 5 sections up in TOC :-/
opinion of one music icon ot important in argument for or against. More trivia than substance.
/* Mixed and other views on net neutrality */
Changed "recently reclassified" to "proposed reclassifying" - the FCC's policy change has not yet been implemented.

allowed not necessary - no restrictios by ... on
/* Legal situation */ Move USA below EU; EU is larger in pop than USA
added phrase "the other co-inventor of the Internet Protocol," to explain why Robert Kahn is being cited.
Copyedit, [[WP:NBSP]], [[WP:PUNC]] straight quotes, [[WP:DASH|dash]]es, [[WP:CONTRACTION]], [[WP:DECADE]], {{' "}}, fix "$218 million dollars".
This just feels a little less, well, biased.
/* Peer-to-peer filesharing */ rm unsourced horribly written sentence. How, many, commas, are, needed?
/* Development of the concept */ I just moved the reference to the end of the paragraph.
This is mentioned on page 2 of the cited document under the Wireless Broadband heading. I believe this is important because the included text does not explain why they oppose complete net neutality.
This section started in 2003, then went to 1860, to 1888, to 2010. It made more sense in chronological order, so I shifted the order of two paragraphs.
/* External links */ added link to saveournet.ca a Canadian pro-NN advocacy group
/* External links */ -- Change NNSquad link from the incorrect nnsquad.com to nnsquad.org

A new link which references net neutrality as "Obamacare for the Internet" was added in the "Opponents" section.
/* Digital rights and freedoms */ fixed grammar
/* Development of the concept */ Changed "recently" to "In August 2010" so that the entry appears more like an actual encyclopedia entry and less like a periodical.
/* Definitions of network neutrality */ Added necessary comma to preserve grammar and clarity.
/* Preserving Internet standards */ Unified citation, added section number
Short description of the Google-Verizon net neutrality pact
/* Law in the European Union */ Minor grammar correction. By the way, the corrected sentence refers to something about to happen "before the end of 2009". Update required, have no info.

/* Definitions of network neutrality */ Tim Wu certainly doesn't believe in treating traffic first come first served, he believes that different traffic types require different modes; but traditional IP is primarily designed for file transfer
/* Opposition to legislation */ Removed "counter-argument" to Wall Street Journal opinion - pure [[WP:SYN|synthesis]]
/* Opponents */ removed uncited reference to Farber's "nickname" "grandfather of the internet" . reason: Citation not provided.
/* Mixed and other views on net neutrality */ add pull quote from Google CEO, citing ref

"Web" is a name, so it should be capitalized.
Original seemed to confuse victim traffic with traffic causing congestion.
Two very small grammar edits: "considered as a father" => removed "as," "Still, other companies" => removed comma
/* Law in Russian Federation */ mislinked spam

{{By whom}} into first sentence. Who is imposing these restrictions???
the article is mostly about a political debate, so it is not surprising that the article discusses the debate

/* Proponents */ Nevermind.. I uh.. got my net neutrality and my tiered internet mixed up...
/* Proponents */ ?.. That's odd. I thought I remember seeing a page on Google that said it was against net neutrality... Citation given here appears to just be for Vonage.
the data retention directive has nothing to do with net neutrality
/* Opponents */ Added one additional sentence to this paragraph, with very-recent info, re: [[First Amendment]] claims.

/* Law in the United States */ US-->U.S.
[[WP:RBK|Reverted]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/174.6.69.193|174.6.69.193]] ([[User talk:174.6.69.193|talk]]) to last version by 12.230.244.188
/* Proponents */ Removed uncited claim from over a year ago
Added opposing article by Robert Kahn and removed opinion "strongly" ~~~~
Cleaned up citation & provided link to on-line copy of story
/* Proponents */ "insure" has a specific meaning, and it isn't "protect"
Deleted "anti-competitive tying". This phrase is not in the article footnoted. Moreover, it would be incorrect. Bundling telecom services is not generally found to violate laws regarding competition.
Reverted 2 edits by [[Special:Contributions/68.207.227.54|68.207.227.54]] identified as [[WP:VAND|vandalism]] to last revision by [[User:AndrewKemendo|AndrewKemendo]]. using [[WP:TW|TW]]
[[:en:User:NicoV/Wikipedia Cleaner/Documentation|WikiCleaner]] 0.98 - Repairing link to disambiguation page - [[Wikipedia:Disambiguation pages with links|You can help!]]
/* Mixed and other views on net neutrality */
/* Arguments for network neutrality */ The word "seminal" & "expresses a personal opinion. In order to use that word here, you need a reference from well known & respected source in the industry.
/* Arguments for network neutrality */ One man's bribe
/* Arguments for network neutrality */ These grandiose statements need sourcing and attribution to an individual. Regardless, they're extreme and unprovable statements
/* Arguments for network neutrality */ Referring to Tony Soprano is inflamatory. If you want to refer to net neutrality oponents as thugs, then just say so. Don't beat around the bush.
/* Arguments for network neutrality */ Of course they'll earn profits. That's not a criticism; it's a fact. Also, the word "huge" is POV -- has the purpose of exaggerating for effect.
There was a lot of POV twisting of words here for the purpose of proving a point. Wikipedia is not the place to prove a point! {{WP:POINT}}
You must provide a title when using the Cite web template, as explained in the [[Template:Cite web|documentation]].
/* FCC Broadband Policy Statement */ add two new proposed FCC principles
